question: What are the absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins in elderly women after consuming elderberry or blueberry?
reference_contexts:
['Human Nutrition and Metabolism
Absorption and Metabolism of Anthocyanins in Elderly Women after
Consumption of Elderberry or Blueberry
Xianli Wu,* Guohua Cao † and Ronald L. Prior 1,3
*U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agriculture Research Service, Arkansas Children’s Nutrition Center,
Little Rock, AR 72202 and †U.S. Department of Agriculture Human Nutrition Research Center
on Aging at Tufts, Boston 02111
ABSTRACT The absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins (ACN) in humans was studied in four elderly women
given 12 g elderberry extract (EBX) (720 mg total ACN), and six elderly women given 189 g lowbush blueberry (BB)
(690 mg total ACN). The two major ACN in EBX, cyanidin-3-glucoside and cyanidin-3-sambubioside, as well as four
metabolites: 1) peonidin 3-glucoside, 2) peonidin 3-sambubioside, 3) peonidin monoglucuronide, and 4) cyanidin-
3-glucoside monoglucuronide were identiﬁed in urine withi n4ho f consumption using HPLC-MS/MS with']
ground_truth: The study investigated the absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins (ACN) in four elderly women who consumed 12 g elderberry extract (EBX) containing 720 mg total ACN, and six elderly women who consumed 189 g lowbush blueberry (BB) containing 690 mg total ACN. The two major anthocyanins in EBX were identified as cyanidin-3-glucoside and cyanidin-3-sambubioside, while four metabolites were also detected: peonidin 3-glucoside, peonidin 3-sambubioside, peonidin monoglucuronide, and cyanidin-3-glucoside monoglucuronide. These findings provide insights into the absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins in elderly women after consuming elderberry or blueberry.

question: What are the absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins (ACN) in elderly women after consuming elderberry extract (EBX)?
reference_contexts:
['Human Nutrition and Metabolism
Absorption and Metabolism of Anthocyanins in Elderly Women after
Consumption of Elderberry or Blueberry
Xianli Wu,* Guohua Cao † and Ronald L. Prior 1,3
*U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agriculture Research Service, Arkansas Children’s Nutrition Center,
Little Rock, AR 72202 and †U.S. Department of Agriculture Human Nutrition Research Center
on Aging at Tufts, Boston 02111
ABSTRACT The absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins (ACN) in humans was studied in four elderly women
given 12 g elderberry extract (EBX) (720 mg total ACN), and six elderly women given 189 g lowbush blueberry (BB)
(690 mg total ACN). The two major ACN in EBX, cyanidin-3-glucoside and cyanidin-3-sambubioside, as well as four
metabolites: 1) peonidin 3-glucoside, 2) peonidin 3-sambubioside, 3) peonidin monoglucuronide, and 4) cyanidin-
3-glucoside monoglucuronide were identiﬁed in urine withi n4ho f consumption using HPLC-MS/MS with']
ground_truth: The study investigated the absorption and metabolism of anthocyanins (ACN) in four elderly women who consumed 12 g of elderberry extract (EBX), which contained 720 mg total ACN. The two major anthocyanins in EBX, cyanidin-3-glucoside and cyanidin-3-sambubioside, as well as four metabolites were identified in their urine using high-performance liquid chromatography coupled with tandem mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS/MS) after consuming the elderberry extract. The study aimed to understand how these anthocyanins are absorbed and metabolized by elderly women.

question: What is the context regarding the absorption and metabolism of dietary ACN?
reference_contexts:
['cently, several papers on the absorption and metabolism of
dietary ACN have shown that ACN can be absorbed in
experimental animals and humans as glycosides (12–23).
We have previously detected the intact glycoside forms in
blood and urine of humans after consuming elderberry ACN
(16 –17). Murkovic and coworkers (20 –22) studied the absorp-
tion and metabolism of ACN in elderberry juice, and showed that
ACN, though in low concentration, could be detected in blood
and urine as intact glycosides. This report documents that addi-
tional ACN metabolites are present in humans after consump-
tion of ACN from an elderberry extract or whole blueberry.
1 To whom correspondence should be addressed.
E-mail: PriorRonaldL@uams.edu.
2 Abbreviations used: ACN, anthocyanins; BB, lowbush blueberry; EBX, el -
derberry extract; MS, mass spectrometer; m/z: mass to charge ratio; SPE, solid-
phase extraction; TFA, triﬂuoroacetic acid.
3 Mention of a trade name, proprietary product, or speciﬁc equipment does']
ground_truth: The provided text discusses several papers on the absorption and metabolism of dietary ACN. It mentions that ACN can be absorbed in experimental animals and humans as glycosides, detected in blood and urine after consuming elderberry ACN or whole blueberries.

question: What are anthocyanins and their significance in the context of elderberry extract consumption?
reference_contexts:
['cently, several papers on the absorption and metabolism of
dietary ACN have shown that ACN can be absorbed in
experimental animals and humans as glycosides (12–23).
We have previously detected the intact glycoside forms in

tion and metabolism of ACN in elderberry juice, and showed that

ground_truth: Anthocyanins are pigments found in plants that give them red, purple, and blue colors. In the context of elderberry extract consumption, they have been shown to be absorbed as intact glycosides in both experimental animals and humans after consuming elderberry ACN (16-17). This indicates their potential for absorption and metabolism.

question: What is the purpose of comparing chromatograms under identical conditions?
reference_contexts:
['spectral data and by comparison with authentic standards. On
the representative chromatogram of subject G (0 –2 h), one

3) and with an m/z of 463.1 and a daughter fragmentary peak
from MS/MS with an m/z of 301.2 (Fig. 3 B). Based upon the
m/z of 301.2, we assumed this peak to be peonidin glycoside or
another methylated form of cyanidin glycoside. We compared
the chromatogram of the mixed ACN standards under the
same experimental conditions (Fig. 1 C) and found that the
retention time of this peak was identical to that of peonidin-
3-glucoside, conﬁrming this peak to be peonidin-3-glucoside, a
methylated form of cyanidin-3-glucoside. This observation
also supports the conclusion from other studies, which dem-
onstrated that for several ﬂavonoids with 3 /H11032,4 /H11032-dihydroxyla-
tion of ring B, methylation tends to occur at the 3/H11032-O-position
(26). Another small peak appeared at 33.1 min (Fig. 3 A, Peak']
ground_truth: Comparing chromatograms under identical experimental conditions helps in identifying and confirming the presence of specific compounds or peaks by cross-referencing them with authentic standards. This method ensures accuracy and reliability in data interpretation.

question: What is the significance of considering ACN not being absorbed in the human body unless they are first hydrolyzed to the aglycone?
reference_contexts:
['lower detection limit under our current conditions would be
0.005 mg/L (based on cyanidin-3-glucoside).
DISCUSSION
ACN have been considered to not be absorbed in the
human body, unless they were ﬁrst hydrolyzed to the aglycone
in the gastrointestinal tract. The poor lipophilic properties of
ACN have led to the conviction that they are underabsorbed.
Horwitt (11) was perhaps the ﬁrst to observe the ACN pig-
ments in the urine of rabbits. Recently, however, several
investigators have concluded that ACN can be absorbed in
both human and animal bodies as intact forms (12 –23). Some
investigators have shown that quercetin glucosides may inter-
act with the intestinal glucose transporter and be absorbed in
that manner (28 –30). Whether ACN could be absorbed by a
similar mechanism remains unknown. Mu ¨ lleder et al. (22)
compared the urinary excretion when elderberry ACN were
consumed with and without simultaneous ingestion of sugar.
The total excretion of ACN with sugar was lower than that']
ground_truth:
The term 'ACN have been considered to not be absorbed in the
human body, unless they were ﬁrst hydrolyzed to the aglycone
in the gastrointestinal tract' suggests that ACN's absorption is dependent on their conversion into an aglycone form. This implies that without this conversion, ACN may not be effectively absorbed by the human body.

['lower detection limit under our current conditions would be

DISCUSSION
ACN have been considered to not be absorbed in the
human body, unless they were ﬁrst hydrolyzed to the aglycone
in the gastrointestinal tract. The poor lipophilic properties of
ACN have led to the conviction that they are underabsorbed.
Horwitt (11) was perhaps the ﬁrst to observe the ACN pig-
ments in the urine of rabbits. Recently, however, several
investigators have concluded that ACN can be absorbed in
both human and animal bodies as intact forms (12 –23). Some
investigators have shown that quercetin glucosides may inter-
act with the intestinal glucose transporter and be absorbed in
that manner (28 –30). Whether ACN could be absorbed by a
similar mechanism remains unknown. Mu ¨ lleder et al. (22)
compared the urinary excretion when elderberry ACN were
consumed with and without simultaneous ingestion of sugar.
The total excretion of ACN with sugar was lower than that']
ground_truth: The lower detection limit for cyanidin-3-glucoside under our current conditions would be 0.005 mg/L (based on cyanidin-3-glucoside).

question: What are two possible pathways that could describe the formation of peonidin monoglucuronide?
reference_contexts:
['Because previous investigators have relied on detecting the
conjugated forms using the difference in ACN concentrations
before and after incubation with
/H9252-glucuronidase, small
amounts of degradation during the incubation might mask any
conjugates that were present.
In this study, we still do not know how the peonidin
monoglucuronide is formed. Two possible pathways could de-
scribe the formation of this metabolite ( Fig. 6). Cyanidin-3-
glucoside could be absorbed intact and some methylated to
form peonidin-3-glucoside in the liver (Fig. 6; Pathway 1).
Either cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside could
serve as a substrate for UDP-glucose dehydrogenase to form
the corresponding glucuronide from the glucose form. For this
to occur, cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside would
have to serve as a substrate for the enzyme UDP-glucose
dehydrogenase, which converts UDP-glucose into UDP-gluc-
uronic acid. UDP-glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) is a unique']
ground_truth: In this study, we still do not know how the peonidin monoglucuronide is formed. Two possible pathways could describe the formation of this metabolite (Fig. 6). Cyanidin-3-glucoside could be absorbed intact and some methylated to form peonidin-3-glucoside in the liver (Fig. 6; Pathway 1). Either cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside could serve as a substrate for UDP-glucose dehydrogenase to form the corresponding glucuronide from the glucose form. For this to occur, cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside would have to serve as a substrate for the enzyme UDP-glucose dehydrogenase, which converts UDP-glucose into UDP-glucuronic acid. UDP-glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) is a unique enzyme that catalyzes this reaction.

question: What is the function of UDP-glucose dehydrogenase in this context?
reference_contexts:
['Because previous investigators have relied on detecting the
conjugated forms using the difference in ACN concentrations
before and after incubation with
/H9252-glucuronidase, small
amounts of degradation during the incubation might mask any
conjugates that were present.
In this study, we still do not know how the peonidin
monoglucuronide is formed. Two possible pathways could de-
scribe the formation of this metabolite ( Fig. 6). Cyanidin-3-
glucoside could be absorbed intact and some methylated to
form peonidin-3-glucoside in the liver (Fig. 6; Pathway 1).
Either cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside could
serve as a substrate for UDP-glucose dehydrogenase to form
the corresponding glucuronide from the glucose form. For this
to occur, cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside would
have to serve as a substrate for the enzyme UDP-glucose
dehydrogenase, which converts UDP-glucose into UDP-gluc-
uronic acid. UDP-glucose dehydrogenase (GDH) is a unique']
ground_truth: UDP-glucose dehydrogenase, or GDH, is a unique enzyme that converts UDP-glucose into UDP-gluconic acid. In this study, it could potentially serve as a substrate for the formation of peonidin-3-glucoside from cyanidin-3-glucoside or peonidin-3-glucoside.

question: What is the purpose of comparing the urinary excretion of individual ACN to the relative amounts in a blueberry meal?
reference_contexts:
['making detection of any single ACN much more dif ﬁcult.
There are /H1102225 individual ACN in blueberry and no single
ACN is dominant. However, in elderberry, two ACN account
for /H1102290% of the total ACN. The second reason for the lower
absorption from blueberry may lie in the form in which the
ACN were given. In the elderberry study, the ACN were in an
extract and thus in a concentrated form. In the blueberry
study, the ACN were given as part of the whole berry. Ab-
sorption from a plant extract will likely be much better than
from the raw plant where the ACN have not been extracted
from the plant cell. When we compared the urinary excretion
of the individual ACN to the relative amounts of ACN in the
blueberry meal (Fig. 5), the proportion of most ACN excreted
in urine was consistent with that in the meal. The exceptions
were with the arabinosides of delphinidin, petunidin, and
malvidin. This may indicate that the arabinoside forms may be']
ground_truth: The purpose of comparing the urinary excretion of individual ACN to the relative amounts in a blueberry meal is to determine if there are any differences in absorption or excretion between the two.

question: What are the characteristics and applications of lowbush blueberries?
reference_contexts: ['Gao, L. & Mazza, G. (1995) Characterization of acetylated anthocya- nins in lowbush blueberries. J. Liquid Chromatogr. 18: 245 –259.']
ground_truth: Lowbush blueberries, also known as wild blueberries or northern blueberries, have a unique flavor profile due to their high anthocyanin content. They are characterized by their small size, deep purple color, and sweet-tart taste. These berries are primarily used in jams, pies, and other desserts but can also be consumed fresh. Their lowbush nature refers to the fact that they grow wild in Canada's boreal forest.

ground_truth: The alkalization process involves several chemical transformations that can modify the composition of cocoa. These changes may affect nutritional, sensory, and microbiological characteristics. Several studies have investigated how this process alters the cocoa's composition.

question: What are the reagents and chemicals used in a metabolomics analysis?
reference_contexts:
['comprehensive metabolomics analysis to identify those metabolites 
showing significant differences along the alkalization degrees, which 
can be considered as potential markers of the alkalization process. 
2. Materials and methods 
2.1. Reagents and chemicals 
Solvents employed were HPLC-grade. Heptane was from Scharlau 
(Barcelona, Spain). MS grade methanol and acetonitrile were from VWR 
Chemicals (Barcelona, Spain), whereas formic acid and ethanol were 
purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific (Madrid, Spain). Ultrapure 
water was obtained from a Millipore system (Billerica, MA, USA). Citric 
acid, adenosine, phenylalanine, theobromine, protocatechuic acid, 
( + )-catechin hydrate, and caffeine were from Sigma (Madrid, Spain). 
Pyroglutamic acid and leucine were obtained from Fluka (Buchs, 
Switzerland). 
2.2. Samples 
A natural cocoa powder sample (CN) and three cocoa powder sam -
ples alkalized at different degrees: light (CL), medium (CM), and strong']
ground_truth: In the context provided, the reagents and chemicals used for a metabolomics analysis include HPLC-grade solvents such as heptane, MS grade methanol and acetonitrile, formic acid, ethanol, citric acid, adenosine, phenylalanine, theobromine, protocatechuic acid, (+)-catechin hydrate, caffeine, pyroglutamic acid, and leucine. These materials were sourced from Scharlau (Barcelona, Spain), VWR Chemicals (Barcelona, Spain), Thermo Fisher Scientific (Madrid, Spain), and Sigma (Madrid, Spain). The water used was ultrapure obtained from a Millipore system.

question: What is the purpose of a medium degree in samples?
reference_contexts: ['Samples A natural cocoa powder sample (CN) and three cocoa powder sam - ples alkalized at different degrees: light (CL), medium (CM), and strong (CS) were kindly provided by']
ground_truth: A medium degree refers to a specific level or stage, likely indicating a moderate intensity or concentration. In this context, it suggests that the cocoa powder samples were alkalized at a moderate level.

ground_truth: MS/MS (Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry) analyses are used in metabolomics to fragment selected precursor ions with voltages of 20 and 40 V in the collision chamber. The reference ions m/z 121.0508 (C5H4N4) and 922.0097 (C18H18O6N3P3F24) are used for proper mass correction, while m/z 119.0363 (C5H4N4) and 966.0007 (C18H18O6N3P3F24+formate) are also analyzed in negative mode to assess the stability of the system.

question: What approach was used to optimize the extraction procedure for cocoa samples?
reference_contexts:
['Ideally, the sample preparation should be as non-selective as possible to 
ensure a broad coverage of the metabolome. 
The approach followed for optimizing the extraction procedure was 
based on the achievement of the greatest number of molecular features 
from cocoa samples. Previous results obtained by our research group 
related to the use of an HPLC-MS-based metabolomics approach to 
reveal cocoa powder adulterations demonstrated that a defatting step 
(to remove fatty acid content), the use of a thermomixer (as it enabled 
the control of temperature), and 30 min of extraction time were the most 
appropriate conditions to carry out the extraction ( Gre ˜no et al., 2022 ). 
Taking into account these conditions, the extraction solvent to perform 
the metabolite extraction from the samples investigated in this study 
was optimized. 
Thus, different solvents and solvents mixtures, including methanol 
(25, 50, 75, 80, 90% in water), ethanol (25, 50, 75% in water), and']
ground_truth: The approach followed for optimizing the extraction procedure for cocoa samples was based on achieving the greatest number of molecular features from the samples.

question: What is the purpose of sample preparation in metabolomics?
reference_contexts:
['Ideally, the sample preparation should be as non-selective as possible to 
ensure a broad coverage of the metabolome.

(to remove fatty acid content), the use of a thermomixer (as it enabled 
the control of temperature), and 30 min of extraction time were the most 
appropriate conditions to carry out the extraction ( Gre ˜no et al., 2022 ). 
Taking into account these conditions, the extraction solvent to perform 
the metabolite extraction from the samples investigated in this study 
was optimized. 
Thus, different solvents and solvents mixtures, including methanol 
(25, 50, 75, 80, 90% in water), ethanol (25, 50, 75% in water), and']
ground_truth: Sample preparation in metabolomics aims to optimize conditions for extracting molecular features from samples while ensuring broad coverage of the metabolome. The context provided discusses optimizing extraction procedures based on achieving maximum molecular feature detection, which aligns with this goal.

question: What does a 95% confidence limit represent in Hotelling's ellipses?
reference_contexts: ['Hotelling ’ s ellipses represent the 95% confidence limit. QC, quality con - trol (green); CN, natural cocoa (yellow); CL, light alkalized cocoa (dark blue); CM, medium alkalized cocoa (red);']
ground_truth: A 95% confidence limit in Hotelling's ellipses represents the boundary within which there is a 95% probability that the true mean of the population lies.

question: What was the reason for the intense ion fragment at m/z 138 in caffeine?
reference_contexts: ['As pre - viously reported by Bianco et al. caffeine showed an intense ion frag - ment at m/z 138 due to the neutral loss of methyl isocyanate ( \x00 57 Da) as a']
ground_truth: The intense ion fragment at m/z 138 in caffeine is due to the neutral loss of methyl isocyanate (57 Da) as a result of the neutral loss fragmentation process.

ion fragment at m/z 163. Subsequently, the same fragmentation pattern

question: How many metabolites were identified among all the metabolites?
reference_contexts:
['olomics in both ionization modes to achieve a broad metabolite 
coverage. Among all the metabolites, a total of 31 could be identified, 
being 9 of them unequivocally identified. Mainly, they were identified as 
amino acids, alkaloids, organic acids, or polyphenols, among others. 
Different trends related to the effect of the alkalization degree on the 
level of the identified compounds were observed. The present data 
provide comprehensive information on the effects of alkalization pro -
cess on the metabolites of cocoa powder samples demonstrating that this 
process has a great impact on their chemical composition. From a 
practical point of view, the evaluation of changes in the chemical 
composition of cocoa powder samples submitted to different alkaliza -
tion degrees by using the metabolomics strategy provides valuable in -
formation for future development and improvement of the nutritional 
and sensory characteristics of cocoa powder samples.']
ground_truth: Among all the metabolites, a total of 31 could be identified, being 9 of them unequivocally identified.

question: What is the purpose of using high resolution-tandem mass spectrometry in targeted and untargeted characterisation studies?
reference_contexts:
['( Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp .) obtained by green extraction technologies. Agronomy, 
11 , 162. https://doi.org/10.3390/agronomy11010162 
Barbana, C., Nardin, T., Pierotti, A., Malacarne, M., & Larcher, R. (2017). Targeted and 
untargeted characterisation of free and glycosylated simple phenols in cocoa beans 
using high resolution-tandem mass spectrometry (Q-Orbitrap). Journal of 
Chromatography A, 1480 , 41 – 49. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2016.12.022 
Bianco, G., Abate, S., Labella, C., & Cataldi, T. R. I. (2009). Identification and 
fragmentation pathways of caffeine metabolites in urine samples via liquid 
chromatography with positive electrospray ionization coupled to a hybrid 
quadrupole linear ion trap (LTQ) and Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance 
mass spectrometry and tandem mass spectrometry. Rapid Communications in Mass 
Spectrometry, 23 , 1065 – 1074. https://doi.org/10.1002/rcm.3969']
ground_truth: High-resolution tandem mass spectrometry (HRMS) is used to provide detailed information about the molecular composition of samples, including the identification of specific compounds and their structural details. In this context, it allows for the characterization of free and glycosylated simple phenols in cocoa beans using targeted and untargeted approaches.

question: What is the purpose of isolation in metabolomics studies?
reference_contexts: ['Segura-Carretero, A. (2010). Isolation, comprehensive characterization and antioxidant activities of Theobroma cacao extract. Journal of Functional Foods, 10']
ground_truth: Isolation refers to the process of separating a specific compound or group of compounds from a complex mixture for further analysis and characterization. In the context of metabolomics, it involves identifying basic metabolites and understanding their data m/z.
